items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout today, 28/12/2022, will cause lake levels to remain high. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Flooding is possible on the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Further rainfall is forecast throughout this week and the weekend. Lake and river levels are high and may rise further, the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains. We are continuing to monitor the forecast and will issue the flood warning if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Due to industrial action, we will be temporarily automating our messages, this message cannot be updated during this time.

items.message: River levels have risen on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck. Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. Flooding is possible from 05:00 PM on 28/12/2022. Further showery rainfall is forecast overnight, we will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Due to industrial action, we will be temporarily automating our messages, this message cannot be updated during this time.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels have risen at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of rainfall overnight and today, 28/12/22.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later this afternoon.  Flooding will affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Levels will continue to rise and then remain high before starting to fall overnight. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.

Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is expected from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. items.message: Water levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Wednesday, 28/12/22 and over the coming days. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. The rainfall today has passed through and further rain is forecast tonight, followed by showers tomorrow. Additional rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low-lying roads and footpaths near local watercourses. Please refer to local authority websites for local road conditions. Please note, from 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

River levels remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall.
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is continuing. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre maybe flooded.  
Further rainfall is forecast today, Wednesday 28/12/22, and over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain elevated.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 12 hours 11mm of rain has fallen at Wroxall.  This is in addition to the prolonged rainfall already experienced over the last week. In the next 4 hours, water will be ponded on low lying land adjacent to the river throughout the river valley. Road, cycle track and footpath flooding is expected. At Langbridge and Alverstone Road Bridge, the river will be close to the top of the river bank. Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road, Sandown may occur from tomorrow morning. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Very small amounts of rainfall are forecast overnight and tomorrow. However, further rainfall is forecast from Friday 30th December. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 15mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech. Whilst only a small amount, it follows an exceptionally wet period of November 2022. Minor flood impacts are likely to be already occuring on fields, rural roads and gardens in Hellingly. River levels are predicted to continue rising Wednesday afternoon, and may approach gardens on Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly from 19:00 28/12/2022. From 19:00 28/12/2022 minor flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. Only isolated showers are expected Wednesday evening and Thursday. The river should begin to fall by 02:00 29/12/2022 in Hellingly, but not until midday Thursday in Alfriston. More rain is forecast Friday, Saturday and Sunday, which will again bring a risk of property flooding. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast.

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Wednesday 28th December. 

There has been heavy rainfall overnight accompanied by strong winds. Rivers have reacted and there remains a risk of flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. Watercourses in the area will remain high throughout Wednesday, although no flooding to properties is expected.  

Rain is forecast to clear this afternoon to be followed by scattered showers. The next frontal system is likely to move in on Friday bringing further persistent rainfall. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated later this afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

Flooding is expected in this area. This means properties are at risk of flooding.

Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

Thursday’s early morning tide at 03:45 on 29/12/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.29 m. The total forecast tide is 5.84 metres Chart Datum (2.79 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Tide levels and waves are forecast to be smaller from Thursday afternoon, with only minimal flood impacts expected. However, very large waves could return Sunday morning 1/1/2023. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide.

Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: Levels have risen in the Washford River, as a result of the rainfall overnight and this morning. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022, and over the coming days in response to any further rain. Flooding of low-lying land is possible from the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. The current rain is forecast to pass through by early afternoon today, followed by some more rain tonight and showers tomorrow. Further rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Please refer to local authority websites for local road conditions. Please note, from 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
Further rainfall is forecast today, Wednesday 28/12/22, and over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain elevated.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

River levels have risen on the River Parrett at Chiselborough gauge, as a result of the earlier rainfall today. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022.  We forecast that flooding is likely for roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. Overtopping could occur from the lower River Parrett. Further rain is forecast tonight, followed by showers tomorrow. Additional rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Please refer to local authority websites for local road conditions. Please note, from 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower River Hull catchment remains in force as river levels have risen in the Cottingham area on Mill Beck due to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near Mill Beck, with low lying land expected to be most affected. Levels elsewhere in the Lower River Hull area are not currently of concern. Further rain is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions in your area. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert is now in force for the Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby. Flooding is possible for the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. River levels are forecast to rise on the river Ouse due to persistent rain through Wednesday, 28/12/2022. Further bands of rain are forecast over the coming days, which may cause river levels to remain high. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.

items.message: The flood alert remains in force for the Upper River Ouse. Flooding is possible for riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Be prepared. River levels are rising on the river Ouse during Wednesday, 28/12/2022 due to recent persistent rainfall. Further bands of rain are forecast over the coming days, which may cause river levels to remain high. We have teams on standby to operate the Foss Barrier if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.

items.message:
This flood alert has been issued as weather conditions along the coast are forecast to cause overtopping waves and spray during the evening tide on 28/12/2022.
The tides will be at their highest between 6:00 PM and 10:00 PM on 28/12/2022.
Areas most likely to be affected are Hendon Promenade and Seaburn Lower Promenade.
We also expect this alert to remain in force for these locations for the high tide between 8:00 PM and 10:30 PM on 29/12/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.
This message will be removed when the high tides causing concern have passed.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent, prolonged rainfall. Levels will continue to rise over the next few days and flooding of fields and some minor roads is expected.  Further rainfall is expected over the coming weekend. Due to a BT fault data from the Woodyates borehole is currently unavailable online, however today's reading is 93.95 metres above sea level.
Looking further ahead next week will be relatively dry, but with the possibility of stormy conditions appearing at the end of the week.

items.description: North Sea at Scarborough - Foreshore Road
